data.title: Aristotle's Plot (1996)
data.meta_description: Tourneur, a self-proclaimed cinéaste, feuds with Cinema and his gang, who are obsessed with foreign action movies.
data.text:
Outlaw cinema. What means to create images in the capitalist perphery? And what about watching them? Pointed, very funny, always self-aware about how Bekolo is subverting the same film world economy that marginalizes movies made in Africa and consume them under that always complicated "African cinema" label, often beautiful. It is about thinking through images on how centuries old forms operate to normalize opression and ways those same images can react to them.

In a separate but not so much note: Aristotle's Plot was produced for that mid 90's BFI series about "a hundred years of cinema" and was DQ because BFI obviously hated being told the truth about their own project. There was one other very odd movie on…

Essential viewing for any devotee of African cinema, because of how it examines and contextualizes this term "African cinema"---the movie explores the limitations of the term, calls into question global perceptions of African cinema, and also gives an update on the state of African cinema and its relation to the rest of the world (in 1996 yes, but most of this is still incredibly relevant today).

In my circles I do not see much discussion of African film industries and African cinema culture, so a self-reflexive movie like this one feels very special---it seems like a great starting point for further learning and discussion.
